div.p: This term is an optional attribute found in BIOGRAPHY PERSONNAME NICKNAME . Its values, abusive and honorific, distinguish between nicknames for women writers that were either meant to satirize and insult or were intended to honour. For example, Constance Gore-Booth was known in the press by the nickname of Red Countess and this nickname had negative connotations. We hope to help researchers trace the way gender operates to both abuse and honour women writers through the application of nicknames.

div.codeblock: <NICKNAME NAMECONNOTATION="honorific" NAMETYPE="literary">The Queen of the Blues</NICKNAME> Public Name given to Elizabeth Montagu to recognize her importance in the Bluestocking Circle.
<NICKNAME NAMECONNOTATION="honorific" NAMETYPE="other">The Lady-in-Chief </NICKNAME> Above refers to Florence Nightingale.
<NICKNAME NAMECONNOTATION="abusive" NAMETYPE="literary">Red Countess</NICKNAME> Negative reference to Constance Gore-Booth.
<NICKNAME NAMECONNOTATION="abusive" NAMETYPE="familiar">Mrs Perfection</NICKNAME> Above is the critical nickname by which Mary Wollstonecraft referred to Elizabeth Inchbald.

div.p: Try to use NAMECONNOTATION for all nicknames, but particularly be aware of this attribute when you have a literary nickname. Since we are interested in the public reputation of women writers, whether or not they were nicknamed negatively or positively is important.
